image.altText: A lightning strike over a marquee on a jetty at a beach

items.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology says about 65,000 lightning strikes were recorded in the 24 hours to 5am.

title.children: Thousands of SA properties without power after severe weather

image.altText: Lowe is at a podium, wearing a dark suit and tie, looking to the right of the camera.

items.synopsis: Take one for the team. That is essentially the message Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe has delivered to the millions of Australians faced with surging mortgage repayments.

title.children: Lowe warns mortgage pain 'not a reason to avoid using the tool that we have' to get inflation down

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Investors are awaiting the latest economic growth figures in the wake of the Reserve Bank raising interest rates. Meanwhile, the ASX has opened higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Philip Lowe defends rate rise, ASX opens higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Philip Lowe says the decision by the workplace regulator to raise award wages by 5.75 per cent was one reason why the RBA raised borrowing costs again yesterday. My colleague Gareth Hutchens joined the News Daily podcast team this morning. He talked about last week's minimum wage decision, and if it will increase inflation and make the RBA's job even harder. But he also pointed out something that was missing in alot of the commentary. The Fair Work Commission was required, for the first time, to think about how it could eliminate some gender based undervaluation of work. It means the FWC now has to think about the pay rates of awards and industries in which the majority of employees are women, to see if their work is being undervalued.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are wage rises inflationary?

featuredLink.title: Will higher wages mean more rate rises? - ABC Radio

children.content: RBA governor Philip Lowe says the decision by the workplace regulator to raise award wages by 5.75 per cent was one reason why the RBA raised borrowing costs again yesterday.
My colleague Gareth Hutchens joined the News Daily podcast team this morning.
He talked about last week's minimum wage decision, and if it will increase inflation and make the RBA's job even harder.
But he also pointed out something that was missing in alot of the commentary.
The Fair Work Commission was required, for the first time, to think about how it could eliminate some gender based undervaluation of work.
It means the FWC now has to think about the pay rates of awards and industries in which the majority of employees are women, to see if their work is being undervalued.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is making gains in early trade after yesterday's fall. The ASX 200 index is up 0.3 per cent to 7,148 with most sectors higher. Miners, consumer staples, and banks are doing the best. Medical devices firm Polynovo (+14.1 per cent) is doing the best on higher sales. Beach Energy (-3.5 per cent) is doing the worst on lower oil prices. The Australian dollar is up 0.2 per cent to 66.80 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market opens higher

children.content: The Australian share market is making gains in early trade after yesterday's fall.
The ASX 200 index is up 0.3 per cent to 7,148 with most sectors higher.
Miners, consumer staples, and banks are doing the best.
Medical devices firm Polynovo (+14.1 per cent)
is doing the best on higher sales.
Beach Energy (-3.5 per cent) is doing the worst on lower oil prices.
The Australian dollar is up 0.2 per cent to 66.80 US cents.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA says household spending is set to remain weaker for some time. And Philip Lowe says the RBA is closing watching the impact on household spending from interest rate rises. "Another complicating element is the very mixed experience across households and firms." "Retail spending on goods has been weak but spending on many services has held firm." Mr Lowe says spending is weakest among households with a mortgage, particularly those who took out large loans compared to their income, and renters. But other households have accumulated large savings during the pandemic and have not run them down. "Other households have very limited savings and few financial buffers," he said. "One of the other indicators we are monitoring closely is mortgage arrears." "These remain very low, although they have increased a little of late." "Banks report that their customers are managing to make their mortgage payments, although many have had to cut back on other spending."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA says some households being hit hard by rate rises

children.content: RBA says household spending is set to remain weaker for some time.
And Philip Lowe says the RBA is closing watching the impact on household spending from interest rate rises.
"Another complicating element is the very mixed experience across households and firms."
"Retail spending on goods has been weak but spending on many services has held firm."
Mr Lowe says spending is weakest among households with a mortgage, particularly those who took out large loans compared to their income, and renters.
But other households have accumulated large savings during the pandemic and have not run them down.
"Other households have very limited savings and few financial buffers," he said.
"One of the other indicators we are monitoring closely is mortgage arrears."
"These remain very low, although they have increased a little of late."
"Banks report that their customers are managing to make their mortgage payments, although many have had to cut back on other spending."

image.altText: A satellite image shows Nova Kakhovka Dam in Kherson.

items.synopsis: On the morning the Nova Kakhova dam was blown up in southern Ukraine, resident Hanna Zarudnia woke to both shelling and flooding. Then she was "surrounded by water from all sides".

title.children: 'The volume of water is colossal': The moment a Ukrainian dam was destroyed and the war changed forever

image.altText: Young white man with dark short hair and facial hair faces the camera with a neutral expression in a park. his arms are crossed

items.synopsis: Needle spiking is when a person is injected with a drug without their consent, and it's unknown how much it's happening in Australian venues.

title.children: Two friends blacked out while at a bar. Then they found the needle prick

image.altText: A young man in a blue t-shirt speaks while an Indonesian officer watches

items.synopsis: The family of an Australian man accused of a drunken, naked rampage in Indonesia has thanked everyone involved in the deal to free him as he makes his way home.

title.children: Australian tourist 'looking forward to putting this chapter behind him' after alleged drunken rampage

image.altText: Cattle walk over a huge mountain of landfill, mostly comprised of old clothes.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest fashion retailers are being threatened with a mandatory levy on garment sales, after many big names failed to sign up to a new scheme to tackle the 200,000 tonnes of old clothes going into landfill each year.

title.children: Just six Australian fashion giants sign up to a scheme to tackle their industry's waste problem

image.altText: A sketch of prince harry sitting in front of a microphone in a courtroom

items.synopsis: Prince Harry is grilled in court as the Mirror Newspaper Group's legal team seeks to discredit his allegations that its journalists engaged in unlawful information-gathering practices to publish stories about him.

title.children: Prince Harry doubles down on 'incredibly suspicious' Mirror articles as he is cross examined in court

image.altText: An American saltwater crocodile opens its mouth underwater.

items.synopsis: An American crocodile managed to reproduce by herself, in a process scientists call parthenogenesis, or 'virgin birth', DNA reveals. Scientists say the discovery suggests the phenomenon may have also occurred in extinct reptiles like dinosaurs.

title.children: After living alone for 16 years, a female crocodile cut out the middleman and had a 'virgin birth'

image.altText: A blue 'for lease' sign outside of a house.

items.synopsis: Research shows mortgage borrowers are paying the highest share of their income on housing costs in at least four decades, but the current situation for renters is not historically unusual.

title.children: Mortgage borrowers have never done it tougher, while renters are back to where they were in 2019

image.altText: Thousands of baby carp captured in irrigation channels along River Murray

items.synopsis: Residents in the Mid Murray are reporting thousands of the fish gasping for air infesting waterways where they haven't been seen before, while experts say it is to be expected after the flood.

title.children: Thousands of juvenile carp seen in irrigation channels along the River Murray

image.altText: A close up shot of a woman holing and looking at her newborn baby in a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Women of migrant backgrounds are more at risk of developing some pregnancy complications, which can limit their choices for their pregnancy care and lead to more medical interventions during birth.

title.children: Caitlin planned for a water birth, but a diagnosis in labour changed everything

image.altText: A pair of hands prepares to tear up a piece of paper labelled "reward for experience".

items.synopsis: A campaign designed to kill off the government's proposed "same job, same pay" changes has been launched. So what do we know about what the government is looking to achieve?

title.children: Same job, same pay: A matter of fairness or a 'dangerous' attack on business?

image.altText: Aryna Sabalenka waits at the net after winning her quarter final match as Ukraine's Elina Svitolina walks past

items.synopsis: Having skipped two press conferences at Roland Garros after being grilled by the media about her personal stance on the invasion of Ukraine, Sabalenka tells reporters she does not want her country involved in any conflict.

title.children: 'I don't support the war': Belarusian tennis star Aryna Sabalenka opens up about invasion of Ukraine

image.altText: A Spanish tennis player gives a thumbs up to his fans in the crowd after winning a match at the French Open.

items.synopsis: Young Spanish star Carlos Alcaraz cruises past Stefanos Tsitsipas at Roland Garros to set up a mouth-watering French Open last-four showdown with Novak Djokovic.

title.children: Alcaraz defies third set wobble against Tsitsipas to set up French Open showdown with Djokovic

image.altText: A man sits at a table wearing a cap and looking straight ahead.

items.synopsis: The PGA Tour, European Tour and rival Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit announce a landmark agreement to merge and form a commercial entity to unify golf.

title.children: PGA Tour agrees to merge with Saudi-backed LIV Golf

image.altText: Brittany Higgins crying while making a statement outside court.

items.synopsis: The Canberra Rape Crisis Centre has called out the Australian media for its reporting surrounding sexual assault and says journalists have been contacting it about Brittany Higgins.

title.children: Canberra rape support centre says journalists contacted it for information on Brittany Higgins

image.altText: A local resident walks on a flooded street after the Nova Kakhovka dam breached.

items.synopsis: A vast Soviet-era dam in the Russian-controlled part of southern Ukraine is blown up, unleashing a flood of water across the war zone, according to both Ukrainian and Russian forces.

title.children: Ukraine villagers flee as dam in Russian-controlled Ukraine destroyed

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe and his board have pushed up interest rates yet again – for the twelfth time in 14 months – because they want to damage the economy further, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Why Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe wants to damage the economy further

image.altText: Portrait of an older woman with short grey hair. She's got a red top on and a black jacket.

items.synopsis: It's deflating to start a new job only to realise what it seemed like on paper doesn't match the reality. Here's how to avoid getting trapped.

title.children: Why 'passion' is the one of the most 'dangerous words' an employer could ask for

image.altText: Unidentified woman with a tissue, image from Pixabay

items.synopsis: Our noses perform some important functions every day of our lives, but we often only notice when disease changes how they work, writes David King.

title.children: Snot comes in many colours depending on what's happening up your nose. But be careful with how you use nasal spray

image.altText: Three surgeons work together in a hospital.

items.synopsis: Federal independent MPs say a culture of public servants "bending to political will" is undermining fairness in government spending and leading to "pork barrelling".

title.children: 'It'll have enormous flow on impact': Independents call for action after hospital rorts

image.altText: A young man in a blue t-shirt speaks while an Indonesian officer watches

items.synopsis: An Australian man accused of going on a naked, drunken rampage in Indonesia will be released from prison after more than a month in detention.

title.children: 'I made a fool of myself': Australian arrested over drunken rampage in Indonesia freed after compo deal

image.altText: A mine shaft

items.synopsis: Australian critical minerals will be more important than ever to fuel growing renewables demand amid dwindling supplies, according to Evolution Mining, which just extended its mine life 17 years.

title.children: Major copper mine's life extended to 2040 to meet demand from construction renewable energy and construction sectors

image.altText: Australian cricket captain Pat Cummins walks beside a green-top pitch at The Oval in the lead-up to a Test match.

items.synopsis: Amid climate protests in London, Australian Test cricket captain Pat Cummins hopes activists will not try to destroy The Oval pitch during the World Test Championship final between Australia and India.

title.children: Guard up at The Oval as Cummins hopes protesters stay off the pitch

image.altText: Freshly shorn sheep walk past a brick building.

items.synopsis: The way sheep grazier warnings are issued has been reviewed due to what many farmers consider "over-forecasting" of the risk to their livestock.

title.children: Graziers have spoken on weather alerts — and the BOM listened

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg, as a younger woman with long dark hair, looks at the camera and smiles.

items.synopsis: Kathleen Folbigg spent 20 years in jail for killing her children. The NSW Attorney General has now extended an unconditional pardon. But there are psychological and practical challenges ahead. Here's what the research tells us.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg's release from prison might seem like a storybook ending but some challenges are just beginning

image.altText: A person wearing black gloves and a hooded jacket uses a screwdriver to unscrew a number plate.

items.synopsis: Criminal networks are using stolen number plates to commit offences and avoid police, but there are simple solutions to stop your car becoming a target.

title.children: Thieves are targeting number plates — how can you protect yours from being stolen?

image.altText: A purple, white and red card stacked beside each other

items.synopsis: The bank launched the cards to help those who have vision impairments.

title.children: How these new bank cards could make the lives of vision-impaired people easier

image.altText: Chris Christie is seated and speaking into microphones during a news conference

items.synopsis: Chris Christie, who served as an adviser to Donald Trump's successful 2016 campaign but has since been an outspoken critic of the former president, has filed paperwork declaring his candidacy.

title.children: Trump backer turned critic Chris Christie enters US presidential race

image.altText: An 8-bit image of a group of people gathered around in a common room

items.synopsis: From dating as a trans man to caring for house plants, here are a selection of video and tabletop games made by queer designers from Australia and New Zealand.

title.children: Eight queer games to play with your friends, on your phone – and even on your Game Boy

image.altText: A man stands smiling next to a brightly coloured spinning wheel with Binance written on it.

items.synopsis: Binance founder Changpeng Zhao has been accused of operating a "web of deception". Who is the ambitious chief executive behind the company which dominates the crypto industry?

title.children: Binance founder Changpeng Zhao and his company are facing charges. How did he become the most powerful man in crypto?
